# 香港的國際金融中心地位

鞏固香港的國際金融中心地位是金管局主要職責之一。旨在促進銀行及支付業界開發與應用金融科技的7項措施，於年內取得良好進展，最佳例子是快速支付系統「轉數快」成功推出。

中國內地與香港資本市場的互聯互通計劃推出優化措施，以及粵港澳大灣區的發展，令香港作為進入中國內地主要門戶的獨特地位進一步加強。香港作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的地位亦更為穩固，本港人民幣金融活動蓬勃發展。

與此同時，金管局致力開拓新機遇，進一步提升香港金融平台的競爭力，包括基建融資、企業財資中心及綠色債券市場。金管局亦加強向海外及內地持份者宣傳香港優勢的市場推廣計劃。在國際層面，金管局於多個區內及國際委員會扮演領導角色，明確體現了香港在相關國際工作的專業知識及承擔。

# 概覽

為加強香港作為亞洲金融科技樞紐的地位，金管局致力落實於2017年9月公布、旨在促進銀行及支付行業開發與應用金融科技的7項措施。該7項推動智慧銀行的措施於年內取得的主要進展包括：

- 成功推出快速支付系統「轉數快」，全面接通不同銀行及儲值支付工具（統稱「電子錢包」）
- 發布銀行業開放應用程式介面（開放API）框架及促進業界落實開放API；
- 提升金融科技研究及人才培訓；
- 加強跨境金融科技合作；
- 修訂《虛擬銀行的認可》指引，並處理虛擬銀行牌照申請；
- 「金融科技監管沙盒」升級版（FSS 2.0）運作順暢；及
- 擴展「銀行易」以促進銀行採用金融合規科技。

金管局轄下金融科技促進辦公室(FFO)，聯同金管局各銀行部門在推動落實上述措施方面擔當重要角色。

隨着中國內地與香港資本市場的互聯互通計劃優化措施的落實，香港作為進入中國內地主要門戶的獨特地位進一步加強。「債券通」全面實施即時貨銀兩訖(DvP)結算模式及國務院宣布境外投資者投資中國境內債券市場的稅務寛免安排，進一步提升計劃的效率及吸引力。金管局亦與內地當局緊密合作，探討及實施多項金融配套措施，便利在粵港澳大灣區（大灣區）生活、工作及營商的個人和企業。香港離岸人民幣業務繼續蓬勃發展，人民幣存款資金池全年上升6%至6,577億元人民幣；人民幣即時支付結算(RTGS)系統平均每日交易額達到10,101億元人民幣的高水平。

金管局積極開拓進一步提升香港金融平台競爭力的新機會。為促進香港債券市場的發展，金管局落實《財政預算案》所提出的「債券資助先導計劃」，為首次在香港發行債券的機構提供資助，並與政府緊密合作修訂法例，擴大「合資格債務票據計劃」下可獲稅務豁免的債券投資收入範圍。金管局亦加強市場推廣活動，向海外及內地持份者宣傳香港的優勢，包括舉辦多項大型及專題外展活動推廣香港為綠色金融、基建融資及企業財資中心樞紐。

在國際層面，金管局領導多個區內及國際委員會。金管局現正擔任金融穩定理事會轄下監管合作常設委員會主席、巴塞爾銀行監管委員會（巴塞爾委員會）轄下監管及實施準則小組，以及東亞及太平洋地區中央銀行會議(EMEAP) 轄下金融市場工作小組主席。

香港金融基建的安全及有效運作，為香港作為國際金融中心的地位奠定穩固基礎。處理銀行同業交易的4個RTGS系統、債務工具中央結算系統（CMU系統）及香港交易資料儲存庫（香港儲存庫）在2018年達到100%的系統可供使用率，高於99.95%的目標水平。透過於內地兩個中央證券託管機構的帳戶，CMU系統繼續協助結算「債券通」北向通交易，以及替相關CMU系統成員持有內地債務證券。

為促進零售支付業的整體安全及效率，金管局於8月根據《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》（《支付條例》）指定多兩個零售支付系統，使其運作受到金管局監察。迄今受金管局監察的指定零售支付系統增至6個。金管局亦對16個儲值支付工具持牌人進行監管。有關持牌人積極推出新產品及服務，致力為客戶提供更多選擇及更佳的用戶體驗。與此同時，電子支票與電子帳單及繳費服務涵蓋範圍，進一步擴展至包括香港與整個廣東省的跨境支付交易。

# 2018年回顧

# 香港作為亞洲的金融科技樞紐

# 推動智慧銀行的措施

金管局於2017年9月公布7項推動智慧銀行的措施，旨在協助銀行業提升至更高層次，並把握銀行與科技結合帶來的龐大機遇。金管局於年內在落實這些措施及為香港金融生態轉型方面，進展良好。

# 「轉數快」

「轉數快」於9月成功啟動，方便銀行及儲值支付工具用戶隨時隨地進行港元及人民幣的跨行即時資金轉帳，用戶只需輸入收款人的手機號碼或電郵地址。共有21間銀行（包括大部分零售銀行）及10間儲值支付工具營運商已加入該系統，為客戶提供即時支付服務及╱或帳戶綁定服務。

「轉數快」在3.5個月內已接獲超過200萬個登記，相對香港人口比例27%。該系統自推出以來處理超過480萬宗交易，涉及總額逾1,049億港元及27.5億元人民幣。

金管局於同月推出香港零售支付共用二維碼標準及相關流動應用程式「香港共用二維碼」(HKQR)，是全球首創將多個二維碼整合成為個綜合二維碼的流動應用程式，方便商戶尤其中小企以同一個二維碼接受不同支付服務營運商的支付方案，無需向客戶展示多個二維碼。

# 開放應用程式介面

開放API是指透過向第三方服務供應商開放銀行的相關數據，更好更方便地融合銀行與其他行業的服務。用家單用一個系統就能在安全環境下享受綜合服務。為促進銀行界研發及提供開放API，金管局於7月發布開放API框架。該框架採用風險為本原則，並分4個階段落實各項開放API功能。截至2019年1月底，20間銀行已開放第一階段約500個開放API接口，涵蓋逾1,000項產品及服務的資料。

# 科研及人才培訓

建基於金管局主導的貿易融資概念驗證成果由香港多間銀行組成的聯盟於10月啟動以分布式分類帳技術(DLT)為基礎的貿易融資平台「貿易聯動」。該平台旨在透過數碼化貿易文件及自動化貿易融資流程，減低失誤及詐騙風險。截至2018年底，已有12間銀行加入成為該聯盟成員。「貿易聯動」與歐洲貿易融資平台「we.trade」於10月簽署《諒解備忘錄》，進行對接雙方平台的概念驗證。金管局亦同步探討「貿易聯動」與其他地區對接的機會，包括與新加坡金融管理局合作推出「全球貿易連接網絡」。

金管局總裁陳德霖先生（左）於「貿易聯動」啟動儀式上。

為培育更多金融科技專才，金管局於1月與香港應用科技研究院（應科院）合作推出「金融科技人才培育計劃」升級版(FCAS 2.0)。FCAS 2.0設有4個項目，適合處於不同職涯發展階段的年輕人才。計劃下有200多名學生受惠。

金管局總裁陳德霖先生（左二）與數碼港主席林家禮博士（左一）、香港應科院主席王明鑫先生（右二）及香港科技園公司行政總裁黃克強先生（右一）出席FCAS 2.0啟動儀式。

# 跨境合作

繼於2017年與深圳市人民政府金融發展服務辦公室（深圳金融辦）簽署《諒解備忘錄》後，金管局繼續加強與深圳的金融科技合作。當中包括金管局贊助「深圳金融科技暑期實習計劃」，讓50名學生到深圳多間著名公司進行為期6星期的實習，體驗當地的金融科技生態；另與深圳金融辦第二次合辦「深港金融科技創新獎」。

金管局副總裁李達志先生（右二）與首批深圳金融科技暑期實習生交談。

金管局亦於2018年與瑞士金融市場監督管理局、波蘭金融監管局、阿布扎比國際金融中心金融服務監管局及巴西中央銀行簽署金融科技合作協議，促進金融科技合作。

在8月，金管局與11間金融監管當局和相關機構公布「全球金融創新網絡」計劃。該網絡旨在為創新型公司提供更有效方式與監管機構進行互動，並促進監管機構之間就創新相關議題的合作。

# 虛擬銀行

引入虛擬銀行將會為香港金融科技應用增添新動力，並為數碼銀行客戶帶來嶄新體驗。虛擬銀行以個人或中小企等零售客戶為對象，因此亦有助促進普及金融。經公眾諮詢，金管局於5月發出《虛擬銀行的認可》指引修訂本，並於8月底接獲約30宗申請。

# 金融科技監管沙盒

年內沙盒的使用穩步上升。為協助建立金融合規科技的生態系統，沙盒於9月起開放予金融合規科技的項目。

截至2018年底，共有42項金融科技或科技產品獲准使用沙盒進行測試，其中28項已完成試行，有關產品亦已於其後推出市場。金管局另接獲220項使用「金融科技監管聊天室」的個案，希望在金融科技項目構思初期取得監管反饋意見。其中有約70%的個案來自科技公司。

<Hong Kong's Status as an International Financial Centre>

Strengthening Hong Kong's status as an international financial centre is one of the core responsibilities of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA). The seven measures aimed at promoting the development and application of fintech by banks and payment sectors achieved significant progress during the year. A prime example was the successful launch of the Fast Payment System "PromptPay".

The optimized measures of the interconnected capital markets between mainland China and Hong Kong, coupled with the development of the Greater Bay Area, further solidified Hong Kong's unique position as the main gateway to the mainland. Hong Kong's status as a global offshore RMB business hub has also been strengthened, with vibrant RMB financial activities in the territory.

Meanwhile, the HKMA actively explores new opportunities to enhance the competitiveness of Hong Kong's financial platform, including infrastructure financing, corporate treasury centres, and green bond markets. The HKMA has also intensified its marketing initiatives to showcase Hong Kong's advantages to overseas and domestic stakeholders. On the international stage, the HKMA plays a leading role in several regional and international committees, demonstrating Hong Kong's professionalism and commitment in relevant international work.

<Overview>

To strengthen Hong Kong's position as an Asian fintech hub, the HKMA committed to implementing the seven measures announced in September 2017, aiming to promote the development and application of fintech in the banking and payments sectors. The major progresses made in implementing these measures during the year included:

- The successful launch of the Fast Payment System "PromptPay", fully connecting various banks and stored value facilities (collectively referred to as "e-wallets");
- Publication of the framework for open APIs in the banking sector, facilitating industry implementation of open APIs;
- Enhancement of fintech research and talent training;
- Strengthened cross-border fintech collaboration;
- Revision of the "Guidelines on Approval of Virtual Banks" and processing virtual bank license applications;
- Smooth operation of the upgraded Fintech Regulatory Sandbox (FSS 2.0); and
- Expansion of "BankEase" to encourage banks to adopt financial compliance technology.

The Fintech Facilitation Office (FFO) under the HKMA played a vital role alongside the banking departments in advancing these measures.

With the implementation of the optimized measures of the interconnection between mainland China and Hong Kong capital markets, Hong Kong's unique position as the main gateway to the mainland has been further reinforced. The comprehensive implementation of the Delivery versus Payment (DvP) settlement mode for Bond Connect and the State Council's announcement of tax exemption arrangements for foreign investors investing in the mainland bond market significantly enhanced the efficiency and appeal of the programme. The HKMA closely collaborated with mainland authorities to explore and implement multiple financial support measures, facilitating individuals and businesses living, working, and operating in the Greater Bay Area. Offshore RMB business continues to develop vigorously, with the annual increase in RMB deposit pool reaching 6%, amounting to RMB 657.7 billion; the average daily transaction volume of the RMB Real-Time Gross Settlement (RTGS) system reached an impressive level of RMB 1.0101 trillion.

Actively exploring new opportunities to enhance the competitiveness of Hong Kong's financial platform, the HKMA implemented the "Bonds Subsidy Pilot Scheme" proposed in the Budget Statement to provide subsidies for institutions issuing bonds for the first time in Hong Kong. Collaborating closely with the government, the HKMA revised legislation to expand the scope of taxable income exempted under the "Eligible Debt Instrument Scheme". The HKMA also intensified marketing efforts to highlight Hong Kong's advantages to overseas and mainland stakeholders, including organizing large-scale and themed outreach events to promote Hong Kong as a hub for green finance, infrastructure financing, and corporate treasury centres.

On the international front, the HKMA leads several regional and international committees. Currently serving as Chairperson of the Standing Committee on Regulatory Cooperation under the Financial Stability Board, the Standing Committee on Regulations and Implementation Criteria under the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, and the Working Group on Financial Markets under the East Asia and Pacific Central Banks' Meeting (EMEAP).

The safe and efficient operation of Hong Kong's financial infrastructure provides a solid foundation for its status as an international financial centre. Four RTGS systems handling interbank transactions, the Debt Instruments Central Clearing System (CMU System), and the Hong Kong Data Repository (Hong Kong Repository) achieved 100% system availability in 2018, exceeding the target level of 99.95%. Through accounts at two central securities depositories in the mainland, the CMU System continued to assist in settling northbound transactions under Bond Connect and holding mainland debt instruments for affiliated CMU members.

To promote the overall safety and efficiency of retail payment services, the HKMA designated two additional retail payment systems in August under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance ("Payment Ordinance") for supervision. As of now, the number of designated retail payment systems supervised by the HKMA has increased to six. The HKMA also supervises 16 licensed stored-value facility operators. These licensed operators actively introduce new products and services, providing customers with more choices and better user experiences. Meanwhile, electronic cheques and electronic bill and payment services have expanded coverage to include cross-border payment transactions between Hong Kong and the entire Guangdong Province.

<2018 Review>

<Hong Kong as an Asian Fintech Hub>

<Measures to Promote Smart Banking>

The HKMA announced seven measures to advance smart banking in September 2017, aiming to help the banking industry achieve higher levels and seize the vast opportunities brought by the integration of banking and technology. During the year, the HKMA made satisfactory progress in implementing these measures and driving the transformation of Hong Kong's financial ecosystem.

<PromptPay>

"PromptPay" was successfully launched in September, enabling users of banks and stored value facilities to conduct real-time inter-bank transfers of Hong Kong dollars and Renminbi anytime and anywhere by simply entering the recipient's mobile phone number or email address. A total of 21 banks (including most retail banks) and 10 stored value facility operators have joined the system, offering immediate payment services and/or account binding services to customers.

Within 3.5 months of its launch, "PromptPay" received over 2 million registrations, accounting for 27% of Hong Kong's population. The system has processed over 4.8 million transactions, involving a total amount exceeding HK$104.9 billion and RMB 27.5 billion.

In the same month, the HKMA introduced the Hong Kong Retail Payment Common QR Code Standard and the associated mobile app "Hong Kong Common QR Code (HKQR)", the world's first mobile application that integrates multiple QR codes into a single comprehensive QR code, enabling merchants, particularly small and medium enterprises, to accept payment solutions from different service providers with just one QR code without displaying multiple QR codes to customers.

<Open APIs>

Open APIs refer to making relevant bank data accessible to third-party service providers, allowing seamless integration of banking services with those of other industries. Users can enjoy integrated services within a secure environment through a single system. To promote the development and provision of open APIs in the banking sector, the HKMA released an Open API Framework in July. This framework adopts a risk-based approach and implements open API functionalities in four stages. By January 31, 2019, 20 banks had opened approximately 500 open API interfaces in the first stage, covering data on over 1,000 products and services.

<Research & Talent Training>

Building on the trade finance proof-of-concept results led by the HKMA, a consortium of banks in Hong Kong launched the blockchain-based trade finance platform "TradeLink" in October. The platform aims to reduce errors and fraud risks by digitizing trade documents and automating trade finance processes. By the end of 2018, 12 banks had joined the alliance. "TradeLink" signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the European trade finance platform "we.trade" in October to conduct joint validation of both platforms. The HKMA also explored potential collaborations with other regions, including the "Global Trade Connection Network" initiated with the Monetary Authority of Singapore.

Under the leadership of the Chief Executive of the HKMA, Mr. Paul Chan, during the launch ceremony of "TradeLink".

To cultivate more fintech talents, the HKMA launched the upgraded "FinTech Career Advancement Scheme (FCAS 2.0)" in January, in collaboration with the Hong Kong Applied Science and Technology Research Institute (ASTRI). FCAS 2.0 consists of four programs suitable for young professionals at different career stages. Over 200 students benefited from the scheme.

During the launch ceremony of FCAS 2.0, Mr. Paul Chan (second from left), Dr. Leung Ka-leung (left), Mr. Wong Ming-sin (third from right), and Mr. Huang Kek-hoong (right) participated.

<Cross-Border Collaboration>

Following the signing of the Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with the Shenzhen Financial Development Services Office of the Shenzhen Municipal People’s Government in 2017, the HKMA continued to enhance fintech collaboration with Shenzhen. This included sponsoring the "Shenzhen FinTech Summer Internship Programme," allowing 50 students to undergo a six-week internship at prominent companies in Shenzhen to experience the local fintech ecosystem; and co-hosting the "Shenzhen-Hong Kong FinTech Innovation Awards" for the second time with the Shenzhen Financial Development Office.

Mr. Lawrence Li (second from right), Deputy Chief Executive of the HKMA, spoke with the first batch of Shenzhen FinTech summer interns.

The HKMA also signed fintech cooperation agreements with the Swiss Financial Market Supervisory Authority, the Polish Financial Supervisory Commission, the Abu Dhabi Global Market Financial Services Regulatory Authority, and the Bank of Brazil in 2018, promoting fintech collaboration.

In August, the HKMA, along with 11 financial regulatory authorities and related organizations, announced the "Global Financial Innovation Network" initiative. The network aims to provide innovative companies with a more effective way to interact with regulators and foster cooperation among regulatory bodies on innovation-related issues.

<Virtual Banks>

Introducing virtual banks will add new momentum to the application of fintech in Hong Kong and offer a novel experience for digital banking customers. Targeting individual and small-to-medium enterprise (SME) clients, virtual banks also contribute to financial inclusion. After public consultation, the HKMA issued the revised "Guidelines on Approval of Virtual Banks" in May and received approximately 30 applications by late August.

<Fintech Regulatory Sandbox>

The usage of the sandbox has steadily increased throughout the year. To assist in building a financial compliance tech ecosystem, the sandbox became available for financial compliance tech projects starting in September.

As of the end of 2018, 42 fintech or tech products were approved to use the sandbox for testing, of which 28 completed trials and subsequently entered the market. The HKMA also handled 220 cases of using the "Fintech Regulatory Chat Room", seeking regulatory feedback during the initial design phase of fintech projects. Approximately 70% of these cases came from tech companies.

# 儲備管理

2018年對投資者而言是困難的一年，投資環境備受多項風險因素困擾，包括美國利率持續正常化引發金融狀況收緊、主要經濟體之間的貿易摩擦升級，以及全球多處民粹主義抬頭及地緣政治風險加劇。環球股市普遍向下，美國國庫券收益率亦隨着美國聯邦儲備局4次加息而上升。在美息趨升下，美元轉強。部分新興市場面對國內嚴峻的政治及經濟壓力，其貨幣顯著下挫。儘管投資環境充滿挑戰，外匯基金在2018年仍錄得109億港元投資收入。

# 外匯基金

根據《外匯基金條例》，外匯基金的首要目的是直接或間接影響港元匯價，亦可運用於保持香港貨幣及金融體系穩定健全，藉此保持香港作為國際金融中心的地位。金管局根據財政司司長轉授的權力及轉授權力的條款，就外匯基金的運用及投資管理向財政司司長負責。

# 外匯基金的管理

# 投資目標及組合架構

外匯基金諮詢委員會為外匯基金制定下列投資目標：

(a) 保障資本；
(b) 確保整體貨幣基礎在任何時候都由流通性極高的美元資產提供十足支持；
(c) 確保流動資金足以維持貨幣及金融穩定；以及
(d) 在符合上述(a)至(c)項的前提下盡量爭取投資回報，以保障基金的長期購買力。

以上目標全面顧及外匯基金的法定目的，並已於外匯基金的組合結構及目標資產配置中反映。

外匯基金大致上分成兩個主要組合：支持組合及投資組合。支持組合持有流通性極高的美元資產，按照貨幣發行局制度的規定為貨幣基礎提供十足支持。投資組合主要投資於經濟合作與發展組織成員國的債市及股市，以保障資產的價值及長期購買力。

為能更妥善管理風險及提高中長期回報，金管局以審慎及循序漸進方式將外匯基金的部分資產分散投資至較多元化的資產類別，包括新興巿場及內地債券與股票、私募股權（包括基建）及房地產。新興巿場及內地債券與股票由投資組合持有，私募股權及房地產投資則由長期增長組合持有。長期增長組合的市值上限為外匯基金累計盈餘的三分之一及未來基金與外匯基金附屬公司存款中與長期增長組合掛鈎部分的總和。

策略性資產組合於2007年設立，以持有政府基於策略性目的而為外匯基金帳目購入的香港交易及結算所有限公司股份。由於這個組合性質獨特，因此外匯基金的投資表現評估並無將其包括在內。

# 於外匯基金的存款

外匯基金不時接受財政儲備、政府基金及法定組織的存款，利率一般與投資組合的表現掛鈎，但主要以未來基金除外。未來基金存款的利率與投資組合及長期增長組合的表現掛鈎，實際利率視乎組合比重而定。於2018年底，未來基金在投資組合與長期增長組合的比重約為50:50。

# 投資程序

外匯基金的投資程序分別以策略性資產配置及戰略性資產配置作基礎。策略性資產配置，即投資基準反映的配置情況，顯示外匯基金為達到投資目標而可作出的長線資產配置。外匯基金以策略性配置作為指引，對資產進行戰略性配置，以爭取超越基準的回報。因此，實際配置往往會與基準配置（亦即策略性配置）有所偏離，而實際與基準配置之間的差距稱為「戰略性偏離」。財政司司長經諮詢外匯基金諮詢委員會後制定投資基準及循跡誤差限額，金管局獲授權決定戰略性資產配置及定出戰略性偏離的容許範圍。投資組合經理可在戰略性偏離的容許範圍內選持倉盤，從短期市場變化中獲利。

# 投資管理

# 直接投資

金管局於8月成立外匯基金投資辦公室，專責投資及相關風險管理職能。該辦公室職員負責直接管理外匯基金約72%的投資，包括整個支持組合及部分投資組合。該部分的投資組合投資於環球定息市場，並透過衍生工具執行外匯基金的宏觀風險管理策略。

# 外聘投資經理

除透過內部職員管理資產外，金管局亦僱用外聘投資經理負責管理外匯基金約28%的資產，包括所有上市股票組合及其他特別資產。僱用外聘投資經理的目的是要運用市場上最佳的專業投資技術為外匯基金投資，以取得可持續回報，並讓外匯基金受惠於多元化及互補的投資方式，以及汲取市場心得與專業投資技術知識。

僱用外聘投資經理的相關支出包括基金管理與託管費、交易費、預扣稅及其他稅項。這些支出主要受市場因素影響而每年不同。

# 風險管理及監察

投資環境越趨複雜，突顯風險管理的重要。金管局為內部及外聘投資經理所管理的投資組合均訂立嚴格管控措施及投資指引，並密切監察對指引及法規的遵守情況。金管局已加強風險評估，以配合外匯基金越趨多元化的投資；另採用風險管控工具來評估在正常及極度不利市況下的市場風險。金管局亦進行詳細的投資表現因素分析，以識別促成不同表現的成因，藉此評估如何充分利用內部及外聘投資經理的投資管理技術。

# 負責任投資

金管局支持負責任投資。例如，金管局已採納證券及期貨事務監察委員會公布的《負責任的擁有權原則》。該套原則旨在協助投資者釐定如何以最佳方法履行其於香港上市公司投資的擁有權責任。就外匯基金的管理而言，金管局已就環境、社會及管治因素制定內部指引，適用於外聘基金經理的甄選、委任及監察程序。獲委任負責主動式管理香港股票組合的外聘基金經理，須在管理有關投資時遵守《負責任的擁有權原則》。整體而言，金管局已將環境、社會及管治因素納入投資及相關監察活動的內部程序。金管局會密切注視環境、社會及管治因素的相關標準的發展，並評估如何能夠將這些標準進一步融入投資程序。此外，為促進負責任投資的國際合作，金管局已成為非牟利組織FCLTGlobal的成員，該組織旨在推動長遠目標為本的業務及投資決定。

# Reserve Management

2018 proved to be a challenging year for investors, as investment environments were troubled by multiple risk factors including continued normalization of U.S. interest rates leading to tighter financial conditions, escalation of trade tensions among major economies, and rising populism and geopolitical risks across the globe. Global stock markets generally declined, while U.S. Treasury yields increased along with four Federal Reserve hikes. Under rising U.S. interest rates, the U.S. dollar strengthened. Some emerging markets faced severe domestic political and economic pressures, resulting in significant depreciation of their currencies. Despite the challenging investment environment, the Exchange Fund recorded HK$10.9 billion in investment income in 2018.

# The Exchange Fund

Under the Exchange Fund Ordinance, the primary objective of the Exchange Fund is directly or indirectly influencing the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate, and may also be used to maintain the stability and soundness of Hong Kong's monetary and financial system, thereby sustaining Hong Kong's status as an international financial center. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is accountable to the Financial Secretary for the management and investment of the Exchange Fund based on powers and delegated authority granted by the Financial Secretary.

# Management of the Exchange Fund

# Investment Objectives and Portfolio Structure

The Exchange Fund Advisory Committee establishes the following investment objectives for the Exchange Fund:

(a) Capital preservation;  
(b) Ensuring that the overall money base is fully supported at all times by highly liquid U.S. dollar assets;  
(c) Guaranteeing sufficient liquidity to maintain monetary and financial stability; and  
(d) Pursuing investment returns to the maximum extent possible under the premise of (a) to (c) above, to safeguard the fund's long-term purchasing power.  

These objectives comprehensively reflect the statutory purpose of the Exchange Fund and are reflected in the fund's portfolio structure and target asset allocation.

The Exchange Fund is broadly divided into two main portfolios: the Support Portfolio and the Investment Portfolio. The Support Portfolio holds highly liquid U.S. dollar assets, providing full support for the money base according to the provisions of the Currency Board System. The Investment Portfolio primarily invests in bond and equity markets of Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) member countries to preserve asset value and long-term purchasing power.

To better manage risks and enhance medium-to-long term returns, the HKMA has been cautiously and gradually diversifying parts of the Exchange Fund's assets into more diversified asset classes, including emerging market and mainland China bonds and equities, private equity (including infrastructure) and real estate. Emerging market and mainland China bonds and equities are held in the Investment Portfolio, while private equity and real estate investments are held in the Long-Term Growth Portfolio. The market value ceiling of the Long-Term Growth Portfolio is one-third of the Exchange Fund's cumulative profits plus the total sum of the portions of future funds and附属 company deposits related to the Long-Term Growth Portfolio.

The Strategic Asset Portfolio was established in 2007 to hold shares of The Stock Exchange of Hong Kong Limited purchased by the Government for strategic purposes. Due to its unique nature, the performance evaluation of the Exchange Fund does not include this portfolio.

# Deposits in the Exchange Fund

The Exchange Fund occasionally accepts deposits from fiscal reserves, government funds, and statutory organizations, with interest rates typically linked to the performance of the Investment Portfolio, except for the Future Fund. The interest rate on Future Fund deposits is linked to the performance of both the Investment Portfolio and the Long-Term Growth Portfolio, with actual rates depending on the portfolio weights. By the end of 2018, the Future Fund had a 50:50 allocation between the Investment Portfolio and the Long-Term Growth Portfolio.

# Investment Procedures

The Exchange Fund's investment procedures are based on strategic and tactical asset allocations. The strategic asset allocation, reflecting the investment benchmarks, indicates the long-term asset allocation the Exchange Fund can undertake to achieve its investment objectives. Guided by the strategic allocation, the Exchange Fund conducts tactical asset allocation to pursue excess returns over the benchmark. Therefore, the actual allocation often deviates from the benchmark allocation (i.e., strategic allocation), and this difference is called a "tactical deviation". After consulting the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, the Financial Secretary sets the investment benchmarks and tracking error limits, while the HKMA is authorized to determine the tactical asset allocation and establish permissible ranges for tactical deviations. Portfolio managers can select holdings within the allowable range of tactical deviations to profit from short-term market fluctuations.

# Investment Management

# Direct Investments

In August, the HKMA established the Exchange Fund Investment Office, which is responsible for investment and related risk management functions. This office manages approximately 72% of the Exchange Fund's investments, including the entire Support Portfolio and part of the Investment Portfolio. This portion of the portfolio invests in global fixed-income markets and executes the Exchange Fund's macro-risk management strategy through derivative instruments.

# External Investment Managers

In addition to managing assets internally, the HKMA engages external investment managers to manage approximately 28% of the Exchange Fund's assets, including all listed equity portfolios and other special assets. The purpose of engaging external investment managers is to utilize superior market investment techniques to generate sustainable returns for the Exchange Fund, allowing it to benefit from diversified and complementary investment approaches, as well as gaining insights and professional investment knowledge from the market.

Related expenses for employing external investment managers include management and custody fees, trading costs, withholding taxes, and other taxes. These expenses vary annually due to market factors.

# Risk Management and Monitoring

As investment environments become increasingly complex, the importance of risk management is highlighted. The HKMA has implemented strict control measures and investment guidelines for both internally managed and externally managed investment portfolios, closely monitoring compliance with these guidelines and regulations. The HKMA has enhanced risk assessments to match the Exchange Fund's increasingly diversified investments, and employs risk control tools to evaluate market risks under normal and extremely adverse scenarios. The HKMA also conducts detailed investment performance factor analysis to identify the causes of different performances, thereby assessing how to effectively utilize the investment management capabilities of internal and external investment managers.

# Responsible Investment

The HKMA supports responsible investment. For example, the HKMA has adopted the "Principles of Responsible Ownership" published by the Securities and Futures Commission. These principles aim to help investors determine the best way to fulfill their ownership responsibilities in listed companies in Hong Kong. Regarding the management of the Exchange Fund, the HKMA has developed internal guidelines concerning environmental, social, and governance factors applicable to the selection, appointment, and monitoring processes of external fund managers. External fund managers appointed to actively manage Hong Kong equity portfolios must adhere to the "Principles of Responsible Ownership" when managing these investments. Overall, the HKMA has incorporated environmental, social, and governance factors into its internal procedures for investment and related monitoring activities. The HKMA will closely monitor developments in relevant standards for environmental, social, and governance factors and assess how to further integrate these standards into the investment process. Furthermore, to promote international cooperation in responsible investment, the HKMA has joined FCLTGlobal, a non-profit organization dedicated to promoting business and investment decisions focused on long-term objectives.

# Performance of the Exchange Fund

# Financial Markets in 2018

In 2018, previously underestimated risk factors emerged in the market, including the pace of U.S. interest rate normalization, the impact of U.S. government trade policies and protectionism on global trade, and geopolitical risks. Global financial markets experienced significant volatility and adjustments.

Escalating Sino-U.S. trade disputes caused great concern among investors. Emerging markets and the Hong Kong stock market began declining repeatedly from early January, with the Hang Seng Index falling as much as 27% from its peak in that month. From the fourth quarter, major European and American stock markets also dropped significantly, recording double-digit declines. Overall, global stock markets declined in 2018, with the MSCI World Index falling 10.4% and the MSCI Emerging Markets Index dropping 16.6%.

In the bond market, due to the normalization of U.S. monetary policy, U.S. Treasury yields generally rose in 2018. However, the bond market still experienced volatility during the year. For example, the yield on the 10-year U.S. Treasury note rose from around 2.5% at the beginning of the year to a 7-year high of 3.2% in November, but fell back to 2.7% by year-end due to investor concerns over Sino-U.S. trade disputes and a shift toward safe-haven investments.

In the foreign exchange market, the U.S. dollar strengthened alongside U.S. interest rate hikes during the year. The U.S. Dollar Index rose 4.4%, while major currencies such as the euro and yuan depreciated against the U.S. dollar by about 5%. In addition, some emerging markets suffered further currency devaluations due to domestic political instability and economic uncertainty. For example, the Argentine peso and Turkish lira fell by approximately 50% and 30% respectively against the U.S. dollar. In contrast, demand for safe-haven investments drove the Japanese yen up 2.7% against the U.S. dollar.

Institutional Functions  

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) maintains effective communication with the public and the market through various channels including media, websites, and public education activities, to enhance public understanding of its policies and operations. Throughout the year, the HKMA continued to strengthen institutional governance, including supporting staff in improving their professional capabilities, strictly controlling finances, and enhancing information technology security, to address challenges arising from implementing new measures and increasing workloads.  

Strengthening Public Engagement  

Media Relations and Social Media  

The HKMA maintains close communication with the media to increase transparency and improve public awareness of its policies and work. In 2018, the HKMA conducted a total of 96 public media activities, including 21 press briefings, 11 live interviews, and 64 other public events. Additionally, there were 39 media interviews arranged during the year, along with the release of 462 bi-lingual news releases. The HKMA also handled numerous media inquiries daily.  

To enhance public understanding of the HKMA’s core functions, the HKMA organized media briefings and workshops for local and overseas media covering multiple topics, including the Linked Exchange Rate System (LER), fintech developments, green finance, and infrastructure financing. In addition to enriching content on existing YouTube and LinkedIn platforms, the HKMA launched an official Facebook page in July to further leverage social media for enhanced public communication.  

Mr. Joseph Choy, Chief Executive of the HKMA (left), collaborated with the Environmental Protection Department's mascot “Big Cheeky Ghost” via social media to promote the use of the New Year’s Cash (Hui Xin Cao).  

Public Enquiries  

The public inquiry service serves as an effective channel for the public to understand the HKMA’s key functions and operations. In 2018, a total of 9,950 queries were processed, approximately half of which pertained to banking policies and regulations, bank consumer affairs, and banknotes and coins – particularly the coin collection programme, bank products and services, guidelines and notices related to the banking sector, the Fast Payment Service (FPS), virtual banks, and the 2018 Hong Kong Banknote Series.  

Figure 1 shows the total number of public inquiries received annually since 2015, while Figure 2 lists the distribution of query types in 2018.

Figure 2 Distribution of Inquiries Received in 2018 by Type  

Publications  

Besides the HKMA Annual Report, the HKMA published two issues of the Half-Yearly Report on Monetary and Financial Stability and four issues of the Quarterly Review in 2018. It regularly updated the Monthly Financial Data Bulletin, providing the latest and thematic information and analysis on Hong Kong’s monetary, banking, and economic matters. Additionally, the HKMA published 13 articles titled “Perspectives,” addressing diverse subjects related to the HKMA’s work.  

HKMA Website  

The HKMA’s institutional website (www.hkma.gov.hk) provides over 60,000 pages of English and traditional/simplified Chinese versions, facilitating public access to the latest information about the HKMA. The site also includes records maintained under Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance, namely the Register of Authorised Institutions and Local Representative Offices, and the Register of Employees Engaged in Securities Activities of Authorised Institutions, as well as the Register of Stored Value Instrument Licensees under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance. Dedicated sections and prominent quick links highlight important initiatives such as FPS, and timely updates such as alerts against telecommunication frauds and locations of mobile coin collection vehicles.  

To promote open application programming interfaces (APIs) in the banking industry, the HKMA initiated an open API platform on its website starting in July, enabling the public to access important HKMA information. The initial 50 sets of open data APIs were successfully launched in July, covering frequently accessed areas like statistics on the banking system and foreign exchange reserves, as well as news releases and mobile vehicle schedules. The remaining 80 sets will be gradually released by mid-2019. To further improve user experience, the HKMA is comprehensively revamping the website design and content to make it more convenient and accessible. The redesigned website is expected to be launched in 2019.  

The HKMA leads by example in promoting the development and application of open APIs.  

Public Education Programmes  

The Information Centre of the HKMA is located on the 55th floor of International Finance Centre Phase II, introducing the HKMA’s work and raising public awareness of monetary and banking affairs. The centre consists of an exhibition hall and library, open to the public six days a week. The exhibition hall introduces the HKMA’s work and the development of Hong Kong’s monetary and banking sectors, offering reading materials and exhibits for research on Hong Kong’s monetary, banking, and financial affairs.  

The currency exhibition area introduces the design, anti-counterfeiting features, manufacturing process, and other interesting facts about Hong Kong banknotes and coins. A renovation project was undertaken in Q1 2018, incorporating interactive elements such as games that combine learning and entertainment, allowing visitors to gain knowledge about Hong Kong’s currency while enjoying themselves. Additionally, an art-inspired purple blossom tree composed of 2,018 transparent cubes made from cut-up non-circulating notes was added to the exhibition area, complementing a mosaic artwork made of Hong Kong coins. The newly renovated currency exhibition area reopened on August 16.  

Guided tours are available for visitors. The Information Centre welcomed over 59,000 visitors during the year and provided 580+ guided tours for schools and other groups (Figure 3). Since its opening in December 2003, the total number of visitors has exceeded 705,000. Adjacent to the exhibition hall, the library houses over 26,000 books, journals, and publications for researching topics related to Hong Kong’s monetary, banking, and central banking affairs. The library also retains the registers required under Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance, namely the Register of Authorised Institutions and Local Representative Offices, and the Register of Employees Engaged in Securities Activities of Authorised Institutions.  

Interactive games introduce the production process of Hong Kong banknotes.  

An artistic purple blossom tree hangs in mid-air with lighting effects showcasing the beauty of its form across different seasons.  

Guided tours are offered at the Information Centre for school groups and other organizations.  

Students and teachers from different districts attended public education lectures.  

To maintain community engagement and enhance public understanding of the HKMA’s work, the HKMA held three public education lectures in 2018, attracting around 1,500 secondary students and teachers. Topics included the linked exchange rate system, Hong Kong banknotes, banking system stability, deposit protection schemes, FPS, stored value instruments, fintech, consumer protection, and employment information in the financial sector. Since its launch in 1998, the lecture series has attracted nearly 60,000 participants.

HKMA Staff  

As part of the government structure, the HKMA employs personnel on non-governmental employee terms to attract individuals with suitable experience and expertise. As a public institution, the HKMA continuously streamlines processes to improve efficiency and cost-effectiveness. The HKMA is committed to maintaining a lean and flexible organizational structure and strives to implement new measures and cope with increasing workloads through staff reallocation.  

The HKMA is an employer that offers equal employment opportunities and ensures employees can work in a discrimination-free environment. The Equal Opportunities Policy applies to hiring, remuneration and benefits, performance evaluations, promotions, transfers/training opportunities, and general conduct.  

The HKMA recruits, trains, and maintains a professional and excellent workforce to fulfill policy objectives and respond flexibly to changing job requirements. The HKMA requires its employees to uphold high standards of integrity and ethics, adhering to strict personal behavior and ethical codes at all times, and acting in the best interests of the HKMA.  

Key Human Resources Data as of January 1, 2019  

Organizational Structure Changes in 2018  

The Office of Foreign Exchange Investment was established on August 1, replacing the previous investment and related risk management functions previously managed by the Reserve Management Department and the Risk Management and Supervision Department. The establishment of the Office of Foreign Exchange Investment highlights the HKMA’s investment role, enhances its institutional image, and enables greater flexibility in responding to market changes to support the continuous expansion and diversification of foreign exchange fund investments.

Compensation Policies and Remuneration Review Mechanism  

The Financial Secretary consults the Governance Committee under his jurisdiction and considers market compensation levels and practices when determining the HKMA’s staff salaries and service conditions. The compensation package includes cash payments and mandatory provident fund contributions, along with some basic benefits. Cash compensation comprises monthly fixed salary (i.e., base salary) and annual discretionary bonuses based on individual performance.  

When reviewing the HKMA’s staff compensation annually, the Financial Secretary consults the Governance Committee and takes into account the committee’s evaluation of the HKMA’s performance in the past year, results of independent financial industry compensation surveys conducted by third-party consultants, and other relevant factors. Individual employees who perform exceptionally may receive special adjustments to maintain competitive compensation.  

The HKMA allocates funds for adjusting annual fixed salaries and discretionary bonuses based on each employee’s performance. The discretionary bonus scheme for investment-related staff aims to link investment performance with compensation. Fixed salary adjustments and discretionary bonus distributions for Deputy Managing Directors and above are approved by the Financial Secretary following consultation with the Governance Committee, with the concerned employees absent during discussions on their compensation proposals. Fixed salary adjustments and discretionary bonus distributions for Senior Managers and below are decided by the HKMA Chief Executive according to the Financial Secretary’s authorization, based on the allocated funds for paying salaries.

茲證明我已審計列載於第167至273頁外匯基金及其附屬公司（「集團」）的財務報表，該等財務報表包括外匯基金及集團於2018年12月31日的資產負債表與截至該日止年度的收支帳目、全面收益表、權益變動表和現金流量表，以及財務報表的附註，包括主要會計政策概要。

# 意見的基礎

我已按照行政長官在《外匯基金條例》第7條下所發出的指示及審計署的審計準則進行審計。我根據該等準則而須承擔的責任，詳載於本報告「審計師就財務報表審計而須承擔的責任」部分。根據該等準則，我獨立於集團，並已按該等準則履行其他道德責任。我相信，我所獲得的審計憑證是充足和適當地為我的審計意見提供基礎。

# 關鍵審計事項

# 按公平值列帳的金融資產及金融負債的估值

請參閱財務報表附註2.5、2.6及40.1。

於2018年12月31日，集團按公平值列帳的金融資產共36,935.89億港元，金融負債共11,338.29億港元。

93%的該等金融資產及所有該等金融負債的公平值為相同資產或負債於活躍市場的報價（第1級參數），或是以估值方法估計，而所用的參數是以可觀察市場數據為基礎（第2級參數）。

其餘7%的該等金融資產的公平值，是以估值方法估計，而所用的參數並非以可觀察市場數據為基礎（第3級參數）。有關金融資產共2,756.31億港元，主要包括非上市投資基金。

鑑於所涉數額龐大及涉及估計，按公平值列帳的金融 資產及金融負債的估值屬關鍵審計事項。

就按公平值列帳的金融資產及金融負債的估值，審計程序包括：

- 若使用市場報價，根據獨立來源核實價格；

# 金融管理專員及外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會就財務報表而須承擔的責任

金融管理專員須負責按照香港會計師公會頒布的《香港財務報告準則》及行政長官在《外匯基金條例》第7條下所發出的指示擬備真實而中肯的財務報表，及落實其認為必要的內部控制， 使財務報表不存有因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述。

在擬備財務報表時，金融管理專員須負責評估集團持續經營的能力，以及在適用情況下披露與持續經營有關的事項，並以持續經營作為會計基礎。

外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會負責監督集團的財務報告過程。

# 審計師就財務報表審計而須承擔的責任

我的目標是就整體財務報表是否不存有任何因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述取得合理保證，並發出包括我意見的審計師報告。合理保證是高水平的保證，但不能確保按審計署審計準則進行的審計定能發現所存有的任何重大錯誤陳述。錯誤陳述可以由欺詐或錯誤引起，如果合理預期它們個別或滙總起來可能影響財務報表使用者所作出的經濟決定，則會被視作重大錯誤陳述。

在根據審計署審計準則進行審計的過程中，我會運用專業判斷並秉持專業懷疑態度。我亦會：

- 識別和評估因欺詐或錯誤而導致財務報表存有重大錯誤陳述的風險；設計及執行審計程序以應對這些風險；以及取得充足和適當的審計憑證，作為我意見的基礎。由於欺詐可能涉及串謀、偽造、蓄意遺漏、虛假陳述，或凌駕內部控制的情況，因此未能發現因欺詐而導致重大錯誤陳述的風險，較未能發現因錯誤而導致者為高；
- 了解與審計相關的內部控制，以設計適當的審計程序。然而，此舉並非旨在對集團內部控制的有效性發表意見；
- 評價金融管理專員所採用的會計政策是否恰當，以及其作出的會計估計和相關資料披露是否合理；
- 判定金融管理專員以持續經營作為會計基礎的做法是否恰當，並根據所得的審計憑證，判定是否存在與事件或情況有關，而且可能對集團持續經營的能力構成重大疑慮的重大不確定性。如果我認為存在重大不確定性，則有必要在審計師報告中請使用者留意財務報表中的相關資料披露。假若所披露的相關資料不足，我便須發出非無保留意見的審計師報告。我的結論是基於截至審計師報告日止所取得的審計憑證。然而，未來事件或情況可能導致集團不能繼續持續經營；
- 評價財務報表的整體列報方式、結構和內容，包括披露資料，以及財務報表是否中肯反映交易和事項；及
- 就集團中實體或業務活動的財務資料獲取充足和適當的審計憑證，以對財務報表發表意見。我負責指導、監督和執行集團審計。我對我的審計意見承擔全部責任。

我會與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通計劃的審計範圍和時間以及重大審計發現等事項，包括我在審計期間識別出內部控制的任何重大缺陷。

我亦會向外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會提交聲明，說明我已符合有關獨立性的相關道德要求，並與他們溝通所有被合理認為可能會影響我獨立性的關係和其他事項，以及在適用的情況下，相關的防範措施。

從與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通的事項中，我會決定哪些事項對本期財務報表的審計最為重要，因而構成關鍵審計事項。我會在審計師報告中描述這些事項，除非法律法規不允許對某件事項作出公開披露，或在極端罕見的情況下，因為有合理預期在我報告中溝通某事項而造成的負面後果將會超過其產生的公眾利益而我決定不應在報告中溝通該事項。

# Report by the Auditor-General

# Letter to the Financial Secretary from the Independent Auditors

# Opinion

I have audited the financial statements of the Exchange Fund and its subsidiaries ("the Group") set out on pages 167 to 273. These financial statements comprise the balance sheet of the Exchange Fund and the Group as at December 31, 2018, and the income and expenditure accounts, comprehensive income statement, changes in equity statement, and cash flow statement for the year ended on that date, together with the notes to the financial statements, including summary of significant accounting policies.

In my opinion, these financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of the Exchange Fund and the Group as at December 31, 2018, and their financial performance and cash flows for the year then ended, having been prepared in accordance with the Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards issued by the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants, and in accordance with the instructions given by the Chief Executive Officer under section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance (Chapter 66).

# Basis of the Opinion

The audit was carried out in accordance with the instructions of the Chief Executive Officer under section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance and the Audit Office's auditing standards. My responsibilities regarding the financial statements are detailed in the section "Responsibilities of the Auditor in Relation to the Financial Statements" in this report. Under these standards, I am independent of the Group and have fulfilled other ethical obligations as required. I believe that the audit evidence I have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to support my audit opinion.

# Key Audit Matters

Key audit matters are those that, in my professional judgment, were most significant in the audit of the financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2018. I addressed these matters in the overall audit and formed an opinion on the entire financial statements, but I do not provide a separate opinion on these matters.

# Valuation of Financial Assets and Liabilities Measured at Fair Value

Please refer to Notes 2.5, 2.6 and 40.1 to the financial statements.

As at December 31, 2018, the Group had financial assets measured at fair value amounting to HK$369.3589 billion and financial liabilities measured at fair value amounting to HK$113.3829 billion.

93% of these financial assets and all of these financial liabilities were valued based on quoted prices in active markets (Level 1 inputs) or estimated using valuation techniques with parameters based on observable market data (Level 2 inputs).

The remaining 7% of these financial assets were valued using valuation techniques with parameters not based on observable market data (Level 3 inputs). These financial assets amounted to HK$27.5631 billion, primarily comprising investments in unlisted funds.

Given the significant amounts involved and the nature of estimates, the valuation of financial assets and liabilities measured at fair value constitutes a key audit matter.

Audit procedures relating to the valuation of financial assets and liabilities measured at fair value included:

- Understanding the valuation processes for different categories of financial assets and liabilities, including relevant control mechanisms;
- Evaluating and testing the control mechanisms, including application controls over computer systems;
- Obtaining confirmations regarding the valuation, existence, rights and obligations, and completeness of financial assets and liabilities;
- Verifying prices from independent sources if market quotations were used;
- If valuation techniques used parameters based on observable market data, evaluating whether the valuation technique was appropriate and the assumptions reasonable, and verifying the parameters from independent sources; and
- If valuation techniques used parameters not based on observable market data, evaluating whether the valuation technique was appropriate and whether the assumptions and parameters were reasonable.

# Valuation of Investment Properties Measured at Fair Value

Please refer to Notes 2.12, 20 and 21 to the financial statements.

The Group's investment properties were measured at fair value amounting to HK$2.5321 billion as at December 31, 2018. The Group also held interests in three associate companies and twenty joint ventures, which mainly engaged in holding overseas investment properties, with these interests amounting to HK$4.4336 billion. Whether directly held by the Group or through associate or joint venture companies, the fair values of these investment properties were primarily determined by independent professional valuers. These valuations involved significant judgments and estimates, including the valuation methods and assumptions used.

Audit procedures relating to the valuation of investment properties measured at fair value included:

- Obtaining and reviewing valuation reports for investment properties directly held by the Group or through associate or joint venture companies, and verifying that the fair values were determined according to the valuations outlined in these reports;
- Assessing the independence and qualifications of the valuers; and
- Evaluating whether the valuation methods were appropriate and whether the assumptions and parameters were reasonable.

# Other Information

The Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority is responsible for other information. Other information includes all information contained in the Annual Report of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority for 2018, except for the financial statements and my auditor's report.

My opinion on the financial statements does not cover other information, and I do not express any form of assurance conclusion on other information.

With respect to the audit of the financial statements, I have a responsibility to read other information in order to consider whether it is materially inconsistent with the financial statements or appears to contain material misstatements. Based on the work I have performed, if I become aware of material misstatements in other information, I would be required to report this fact. In this regard, I have no such reports.

# Responsibilities of the Chief Executive and the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee in relation to the financial statements

The Chief Executive is responsible for preparing true and fair financial statements in accordance with the Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards issued by the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants and the instructions issued by the Chief Executive Officer under section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance (Chapter 66), and implementing internal controls that the Chief Executive considers necessary to ensure that the financial statements are free from material misstatement due to fraud or error.

In preparing the financial statements, the Chief Executive is responsible for assessing the Group's ability to continue as a going concern, and disclosing matters related to going concern where applicable, and using going concern as the basis of preparation of the financial statements.

The Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee is responsible for overseeing the Group's financial reporting process.

# Responsibilities of the Auditor in Relation to the Financial Statements

My objective is to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the entire financial statements are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue an auditor's report containing my opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but it cannot guarantee that the audit conducted in accordance with the Audit Office's auditing standards will detect any material misstatement. Material misstatements may arise from fraud or error, and would be considered material if individually or in aggregate, they could influence the economic decisions of users of the financial statements.

During the audit conducted in accordance with the Audit Office's auditing standards, I will exercise professional judgment and maintain professional skepticism. I will also:

- Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement in the financial statements arising from fraud or error; design and perform audit procedures to address these risks; and obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence to support my opinion. As fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omission, or override of internal controls, the risk of not detecting material misstatements arising from fraud is higher than the risk of not detecting misstatements arising from errors;
- Understand the internal control relevant to the audit to design appropriate audit procedures. However, this does not constitute an opinion on the effectiveness of the Group's internal control;
- Evaluate whether the accounting policies adopted by the Chief Executive are appropriate and whether the accounting estimates and related disclosures are reasonable;
- Determine whether the use of the going concern basis of preparation by the Chief Executive is appropriate, and based on the audit evidence obtained, determine whether there are material uncertainties related to events or conditions that may cast significant doubt on the Group's ability to continue as a going concern. If I conclude that there are material uncertainties, I will need to draw the users' attention to the relevant disclosure in the financial statements. If the relevant disclosure is insufficient, I shall issue an auditor's report with a qualified opinion. My conclusions are based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of the auditor's report. However, future events or circumstances may lead to the Group being unable to continue as a going concern;
- Evaluate the overall presentation, structure and content of the financial statements, including disclosures, and whether the financial statements present fairly the transactions and events; and
- Obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of entities or business activities within the Group to form an opinion on the financial statements. I am responsible for directing, supervising and performing the group audit. I bear full responsibility for my audit opinion.

I will communicate with the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee regarding the scope and timing of the planned audit and major audit findings, including any significant deficiencies in internal control identified during the audit period.

I will also submit a statement to the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee confirming that I have complied with the relevant ethical requirements regarding independence, and communicate all relationships and other matters that I reasonably believe may affect my independence, as well as the relevant safeguards in applicable situations.

From the matters communicated with the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, I will determine which matters are most significant for the audit of the current financial statements and therefore constitute key audit matters. I will describe these matters in the auditor's report unless legal or regulatory restrictions prevent public disclosure of a particular matter, or in exceptional rare cases, when I decide not to communicate the matter in the report because the negative consequences of communicating the matter would outweigh the public interest.
